history.content:
Off of the top of my head, I think graphs were mentioned in every CS course I took to complete the CS degree (also, a couple of sociology / linguistics courses (modelling human social groups in the former, modelling sentence syntax/semantics and language families for the latter).

They were taught in so many courses because the topic is very fundamental to CS. You can model most things as graphs, some of which you've encountered in those classes you mentioned:

  • models of human social networks
  • models of computer networks
  • models of physical networks (e.g. transportation of goods)
  • models of any systematic process (cf a graphical representation of following a procedure / algorithm)
    • specifically, models of how computer programs work (either the flow of the code itself, or models like automata / Turing machines)
  • models of anything with states (e.g. modelling a randomized process like Markov processes or the structure of the subproblems in any DP algorithm)
    • including things that we only have sketchy state representations of (e.g. human language models like n-gram models)

Also, there are things that aren't really inherently graphs, but that we can convert into graphs (e.g. all of the reductions between NP-complete problems you've learned in CS170, or any feature representation of any real-world phenomenon that we use graph-based ML algorithms like random forests or neural networks).

And I'm sure other things that are slipping my mind right now, or that I just don't know.

So yes, every class that teaches about graphs does so for good reasons: because they're applicable to the topic. Sometimes there's overlap, and sometimes there's not. Aside from 61A and 61B (as intro courses, they'll naturally have more overlap with advanced courses), the other 4 courses you mention don't have much overlap.

(170 and 188 has the most overlap out of the four, but they're not prereqs for each other, so each class can't assume that the student already knows the basic topics.)

(61B and 170 also has a lot of overlap, but empirically, I know that many students have forgotten what they've learned in 61B, unfortunately, sometimes including basic terminology. Whether for better or for worse, the course staff has elected to simply do a speedy review of the material, as opposed to simply assuming students have already fully mastered 61B material. This is more a pedagogy question about what prereqs means, than anything specific about graphs)

For your final question: in order to understand an advanced technique, you (usually) should start by mastering the basic techniques. That's what college is for. You can learn the state-of-the-art algorithms once you're in industry/grad school, once you have a solid mastery of the fundamentals.

children.subject: I think he is Linguistics and sociology minors.

There isn't a sociology minor.

My majors were CS, Sociology, and Linguistics. I was going a Classics minor (Latin studies) for a while, but gave up when TA-ing + research took up too much of my time.

The linguistics courses I took were Ling5, Ling24, Ling100, Ling105, Ling110, Ling115, Ling120, Ling125, Ling130, Ling160.
You did 3 majors? And graduated in 3 years? Congrats.
How do you know? You are not steven bi. Or are you.
I think most people who know me know that I would happily stay at Berkeley for as much time as the school would allow me, just continuously adding more majors.

Steven what linguistics classes did you take?

Also did you do any other majors or minor apart from eecs?

history.content:
Graphs are mentioned in CS 61A, then taught in CS 61B, then taught in CS 70, then mentioned in CS 61C, then taught in CS 170, then mentioned in CS 188. These are only the classes I know off the top of my head. Why do they keep teaching graphs over and over?

I feel like this is wasting students time; they could be teaching things we haven't learned. Moreover, they keep on teaching the same concepts: terminology, Dijikstra's algorithm, minimum spanning trees, trees and a few other topics. One answer is that "a lot of applications like social networks use graphs." This may be true but Facebook surely uses more sophisticated graph algorithms than what we're learning. Why not teach students that?
history.subject: Why are graphs so important?
